title: July 1
description:
Our Great Alaskan Holiday only lasted one week but it was packed solid, like glacier ice.

We rented an RV and explored the Kenai Peninsula, a natural wonderland south of Anchorage. We saw bald eagles, sea otters, puffins, whales, countless birds and even brown bears. We biked, hiked, kayaked, canoed, rode horses, went on boats, flew a seaplane and got pulled by sled dogs.

children.title: RV
children.description: We took a plane from Oakland to Anchorage. On our first morning, we picked up four rental bikes and one rental RV. We immediately drove off toward the Kenai Peninsula.

children.title: Rainbow
children.description:
Right off the bat we started seeing very Alaska-ey things.

Like this rainbow over the icebergs coming off Portage Glacier.

children.title: Portage Glacier
children.description:
We're at the visitor center for Portage Glacier, but the glacier itself has receded rapidly over the last few years. Its diminished self can be found a few miles away.

For the people of Alaska, global warming isn't an abstract theory; it's just plain observable fact.

children.title: Moose
children.description:
Just about the only creature we DIDN'T see in the wild was moose; we saw this specimen at the Alaska Wildlife Conservation Center.

Locals told us we'd see moose at every turn. Did they smell us coming?

children.title: Peekaboo
children.description: Of course, Felix and Milo's favorite spot in the RV was the bed chamber above the driver's seat.

children.title: Table
children.description: The main cabin featured a comfortable booth perfect for eating and playing card games.

children.title: Bed
children.description: Felix and Milo's sleeping quarters.

children.title: Goofs
children.description: The simple fact of being in a RV was a constant source of merriment.

children.title: Lunch
children.description: Bon app√©tit

children.title: Dishes
children.description:
Our RV came with all the modern conveniences. It had a bathroom (toilet, sink and shower) and a kitchen (stove top, oven, microwave, fridge and kitchen sink).

It took reading the manual a few times, but we even figured out how to "dump" the RV (it's exactly what it sounds like).

children.title: Morning Cuddle
children.description: The parent's bed was in the back in the RV. Milo slept with Felix but he sneaked in with the parents for morning cuddles.

children.title: Sleepy Head
children.description: Good morning, sleepy head.

children.title: Seward
children.description: We spent two nights in Seward. The town was at the heart of the Alaska Gold Rush in the late 1890's.

children.title: Mural
children.description: Nowadays, Seward lives on fishing and tourism.

children.title: Kenai Fjord
children.description:
Cruising Resurrection Bay.

We saw humpback whales, sea otters, one seal and countless birds including horned puffins, tufted puffins and oyster catchers.

children.title: Cruise
children.description: Keeping an eye out for the tail of the humpback whale.

children.title: Otter
children.description:
See that dot? That's a sea otter. Did you know that its fur has over one million hair per square inch? No wonder it was nearly made extinct by fur traders.

Here's another bit of trivia that otter interest you: sea otters often keep a choice rock in the folds of their fur. They use it as a tool to break shellfish.

children.title: Kayak
children.description: The boat dropped us on Fox Island for a little kayaking.

children.title: Fox Island
children.description:
Early last century, Russian fur traders raised arctic foxes on this island. The imposing cliffs and pebbled beaches in protected coves made for a natural, unescapable fox farm.

The fur trade ended around 1930. The foxes have since been removed because they are not indigenous to this region and they were threatening the local ecosystem -- they're really good at eating bird eggs.

children.title: Exit Glacier
children.description:
Back on the mainland, we hiked to Exit Glacier, which is also receding.

Glaciers are formed by snow accumulating and compacting year after year.

children.title: Glacial
children.description: Standing next to a glacier is like standing in front of an open freezer. There is a definite chill in the air.

children.title: Trail Rides
children.description:
We drove our RV to Bardy's Trail Rides to experience four legged transportation.

Three out of four Moses had never gone horse riding before.

children.title: Horse
children.description: Lucie, the only Moses to have been on a horse, had mixed feelings about the whole deal. She prefers riding things that have pedals instead of stirrups.

children.title: Hike
children.description: We took a beautiful stroll at at leisurely pace through the streams and meadows.

children.title: Snack
children.description: The hardest task was to keep the horses from taking snack breaks. They were much more interested in the succulent grass than the human on their back.

children.title: Stream
children.description: Lucie crosses a stream on her horse, L'Amour.

children.title: Gus
children.description: Dean is on Gus. Felix is on Frisco.

children.title: Frisco
children.description: Felix and Frisco.

children.title: Ranger
children.description: Milo and Ranger.

children.title: Water Break
children.description:
Down to the river for a sip.

While it was fun, we can't say we really bonded with these beasts. Dean thought it was like riding a slow, uncontrollable motorcycle. That poops.

children.title: Road
children.description: Scenic stop on our way to the tip of the Kenai peninsula.

children.title: Dean
children.description: Dean and the majestic snow-covered mountain range.

children.title: Homer Spit
children.description:
Our next destination: Homer, at the tippy end of the Kenai peninsula.

More specifically, we were headed to Homer Spit, shown in this picture. It's a narrow 5-mile gravel bar that extends into Kachemak Bay.

children.title: Spit Shine
children.description: Our campsite on Homer Spit.  Bald eagles overhead, glacier-rich mountains across the bay.

children.title: Bald Eagle
children.description:
Bald eagles are Homer's pigeons. They're EVERYwhere. They bicker over food scraps. We saw one being chased by three crows.

They lacked the majesty we expected from our national bird.

children.title: RV Park
children.description: We stayed at Heritage RV Park, smack on the middle of the Homer Spit.

children.title: Ice Cream
children.description:
10:30pm, time for ice cream on the beach.

It never got dark. The sun would lower behind the mountains, move sideways for 2 or 3 hours and then rise back up.

children.title: Evening
children.description:
11:30pm.

The kids stayed up later and later with each passing night. We noticed the local children also stayed up very late. Clearly, Alaskans are determined to make the most of their summer. They'll sleep it off during the long winter.

children.title: Midnight
children.description:
Midnight. This is as dark as it got.

Even on an overcast night, it was light enough to read a book by the midnight sun.

children.title: Salmon
children.description: Fishing is both big business and the state sport.

children.title: Windy
children.description: Aboard the good ship Danny J., on the way to Halibut Cove.

children.title: Birds
children.description:
The Danny J took us by Gull Island, a bird sanctuary.

We saw glaucous-winged gulls, pelagic cormorants, tufted puffins, pigeon guillemots, horned puffins, and red-faced cormorants.

Gull Island is a very noisy place.

children.title: Gull Island
children.description: Gull Island is home to a large colony of black-legged kittiwakes.  These are exploding into the air because an immature bald eagle is hopping around on the other side of these rocks, trying to eat their eggs.

children.title: Murre
children.description: These common murres used to nest on the rocky top of Gull Island, but they all fled to the safety of the water because of there's now so many bald eagles.

children.title: Halibut Cove
children.description: Arriving at Halibut Cove, a tiny village tucked away on the far side of Kachemak Bay.

children.title: Stilts
children.description: Most of the houses on the waterfront are perched on stilts.

children.title: Danny J
children.description: The Danny J docks.

children.title: Fierce
children.description: Okay, okay. No matter how may bald eagles we saw, they did still have more panache than the common pigeon.

children.title: Scavengers
children.description:
Mostly, we were disappointed that the eagles didn't act like apex predators, but more like scavengers.

They'd steal the eggs of the other birds on Gull Island. They'd scrabble amongst the seagulls to snatch a choice fish carcass. They never actually picked fight with anyone remotely their own size, or indeed a single live animal.

children.title: Post Office
children.description: Halibut Cove is home to America's only floating post office. Some of you may have received a postcard mailed from there.

children.title: Beach Play
children.description:
Playing on the beach on the Homer Spit.

In case you are wondering: no, we never went for a swim. We saw exactly one swimmer in Alaska, and she looked certifiably loony.

children.title: Flotsam
children.description: Aaaaaawwwww

children.title: King Crab
children.description: Milo vs. King Crab

children.title: Bald Mountain
children.description:
The challenge: see some wild brown bears, a.k.a. grizzlies.

Bald Mountain Air specializes in just that thing.

children.title: Seaplane
children.description: The bears don't live near the humans, so the humans went to the bears.

children.title: Milo
children.description: Passenger Milo

children.title: Felix
children.description: Passenger Felix

children.title: Landing
children.description: We landed on a tidal river. After offloading the passengers, the pilot pushed the plane to the middle so that it wouldn't end up on dry land when the tide receded.

children.title: Line
children.description:
We were instructed to walk in an orderly line and stick close together so as not to scare away the bears.

Scaring away the bears was much more likely than being attacked by them. At least that's what our guide claimed.

children.title: Observing
children.description: Felix and Milo were the only children in the group. Half the contingent was a group of Austrian reporter filming a documentary for Austrian TV.

children.title: Wild Iris
children.description: This one goes to Iris. The fields were bursting with wild flowers: irises, lilies, lupin and more.

children.title: Monocular
children.description: See anything yet?

children.title: Bears
children.description: Success! We lucked into a large group of brown bears.

children.title: More Bears
children.description:
It turns out that bears don't lead the most exciting lives. They eat grass. Sometime they go for a little run or wrestle briefly with a fellow bear. Then they eat more grass. Then they poop.

The highlight was seeing some bears actually mate. Sorry, no photos. This is a G-rated website.

children.title: Nap
children.description: Once you get over the novelty, watching bears is a lot like watching cows graze. Our attention started to wander after an hour. The Austrian team relentlessly kept at it.

children.title: iPhone
children.description:
Lucie takes a nap. Milo plays on the iPhone.

Both of them are sporting stylish thigh-high boots. The boots were needed to get out of the seaplane.

children.title: Dean
children.description: Dean and the grizzlies.

children.title: Felix
children.description: Felix and the grizzlies.

children.title: Milo
children.description: Milo and the grizzlies.

children.title: Lucie
children.description: Lucie and the grizzlies.

children.title: Family
children.description: All of us and the grizzlies.

children.title: Plane
children.description: We hiked back the plane. Getting it back in a good position was a long process.

children.title: Plane II
children.description: The Moses men helped with the plane preparations.

children.title: Rope
children.description: Almost ready for boarding.

children.title: Take Off
children.description: Our group was in two planes. Each plane held 9 passengers + the pilot.

children.title: Milky
children.description: A view of the other plane about to take off.

children.title: Delta
children.description: River delta.

children.title: Mountain Tops
children.description: Snow-covered mountain tops.

children.title: Glacier
children.description: Our pilot flew some corkscrew turns right above this glacier. Breathtaking.

children.title: Whales
children.description:
About to land in the lake right next to Homer Spit.

Not pictured: during our flight home, we circled for a long time above a massive humpback whale that gave us a first class show. It breached, flapped, flopped, twirled and wagged its flippers. The pilots swore they had never seen anything like it.

children.title: Spit
children.description: The Homer Spit. You can't see it from here, but our RV park is about half way down this stretch of land.

children.title: Home
children.description: Home is where you hook up.

children.title: Stick
children.description: Playing with sticks is still a very highly rated activity for this little boy.

children.title: Stick II
children.description: Milo vs. the smoke.

children.title: Campfire
children.description: Roasting marshmallows for s'mores doesn't feel quite right when the evening is so damn bright.

children.title: Junk Yard
children.description: We never quite figured out whether this was a boat junkyard, an artist colony or perhaps both at the same time.

children.title: Coffee Shop
children.description: Relaxing at a coffee shop for ice cream and a game of Gubs, our card game of the moment.

children.title: Picnic
children.description: Picnic on Moose River, a.k.a. Mooseless River.

children.title: Canoe
children.description: Digestive canoe break.

children.title: Paddling
children.description: Felix is a good paddler.

children.title: Kennel
children.description:
Mr. Seavey's kennel raises dogs to race in the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race, the most popular sporting event in Alaska.

They help finance their team by giving tours. Because even if you win 1st prize, you don't even break even.

children.title: Demo
children.description: Our guide was one of the actual dog trainers. He was very passionate about his work. He demonstrated all the different dog gear on the most docile dog we've ever met.

children.title: Puppy
children.description: Few things are cuter than two-week old puppies.

children.title: Baby Dog
children.description:
Junior Baby Dog made the trip to Alaska specifically for a visit to this kennel. We are sad to report that the original Baby Dog was lost earlier this year during our trip to A√±o Nuevo.

Junior Baby Dog has proven to be a pale substitute.

children.title: Puppy Love
children.description: For the rest of the day, Felix and Milo pleaded for a puppy of their own.

children.title: Puppies
children.description:
As cute and little as they were, those puppies were already very smelly. The whole kennel smelled something awful.

Sled dogs have a very high metabolism. They eat a huge amount of calories daily, which keeps them warm in low temperatures. Because of their high meat / high fat diet, they fart like maniacs.

children.title: Harness
children.description: When the harness came out, all the dogs started to bark excitedly. "Pick me! Pick me! Pick me! Pick me!"

children.title: Sled Ride
children.description: Those dogs love to run. Pulling tourists around during the summer months is a good way to keep them in shape.

children.title: Dogs
children.description: Our sled had big chunky wheels. Not as thrilling as being pulled on snow but pretty darn fun anyway (expect for that dog fart smell -- pfffew).

children.title: Husky
children.description:
This here's Hugo the Husky. Contrary to popular belief, purebred huskies don't make good sled dogs. All the Class A sled dogs are mutts that happen to have some husky blood.

Hugo's just kept around for his good looks.

children.title: Walmart
children.description:
We spent our last evening in Alaska in Anchorage, getting ready to return our bikes and RV before heading for our flight home.

We had planned to spend the night at the local Walmart. We had heard from many sources that Walmart welcome RVs to stay on their parking lot overnight.

children.title: No Parking
children.description:
To our dismay, the Walmarts in Anchorage were NOT welcoming. We tried a couple of them but signs made it very clear we could not stay there the night.

In the end, we park on the side of the road near our RV rental place. Noone came in the middle of the night to make us move. All is well.
